wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement News Roundup 9/18/2015
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top employee engagement articles from around the industry to keep you informed and inspire positive impact in your organization.

How Employee Engagement Benefits your Bottom Line

In a world where you can job surf and hire top talent from across the globe, it has become even more important to employers to find new ways to engage and retain their top employees. The bottom line: employers need to invest in their employees. The article provides advice from HR experts on how to accomplish this; be transparent, give feedback, set clear objectives and create deeper connections with your employees. If you can do this, the payoff will be huge.

The Unlikely Reasons Why We’re More Satisfied At Work

According to a Gallup study, 57% of working Americans reported they are completely satisfied with the amount of vacation time and health benefits provided to them, up more than 10% in the past decade. Yet are companies really offering their employees better benefits or have we lowered our expectations? The author discusses how flexible work schedules, stronger manager-employee relationships and more engaging work cultures may be more valuable to employees than their income, and may be the reason behind our satisfaction spikes.

5 ways to incorporate CSR into leadership development

The best way to learn is by doing. This is why the author suggests social saboticals’ as a way of immersing your leaders into volunteer-type programs to gain valuable skills, learn to adapt and better understand the importance of CSR within business. Many successful leaders have taken part in this innovative project, but there are other ways to incorporate CSR into your leadership development such as linking development to mission and vision, start simple, and adapt concepts to meet your needs. If you can follow the five steps outlined in the article you can turn high potential emerging leaders into extremely effective ones.

Survey: Most Americans Expect Businesses to Behave Ethically; 10% Trust Them to Do So

A recent Princeton study found that 76% of Americans feel it is very important that businesses limit their environmental damage. Furthermore, 88% believe companies should contribute to charities, and 85% believe they should take a leadership role in helping society in ways that go beyond their business operations. This article discusses the importance for businesses to communicate their efforts to their employees and provides insight into finding the appropriate channel to do so. For example, social media proved to be the preferred medium, with 45% claiming it is very effective’ and 38% claiming it is somewhat effective’ to spread word on a company’s involvement.

New IRF Research Study Evaluates Impact of Non-Core Job Roles of Employee Engagement

The Incentive Research Foundation (IRF) is about to release it’s latest research study, Engaged in What? which examines the broad themes, measurements and importance of roles in employee engagement. Previews to the study show that employees have always been at the core of employee engagement initiatives, but as the definition is constantly changing employers must learn to adapt their strategies to avoid employee burnouts and increase performance and retention. Interestingly, the study found that non-core job roles (innovators, team players, continuous self-improvers) can increase both engagement and company success. The trick is for companies to prioritize these for maximum results.
